summary.p: This bundle (35-3020 palm leaf manuscript) contains the first 3 pariccheda-s from the Nirṇayasindhu of Bhaṭṭakamalākara in Telugu script. The first one is the Kālanirṇayapariccheda, the second one is the Navasaṃvatsarakṛtyapariccheda, and the last one is the Prakīrṇapariccheda. The text is incomplete.

The Nirṇayasindhu is composed by Kamalākarabhaṭṭa. He has given an introduction about his family in the very beginning of the text. His grandfather was Nārāyaṇabhaṭṭa, his parents was Rāmakṛṣṇabhaṭṭa and Umādevī, and Divākarabhaṭṭa and Lakṣmaṇabhaṭṭa were his brothers. Though he has composed many works, the Nirṇayasindhu, Vivādatāṇḍava, and the Śūdrakamalākara are his most famous works on Dharmaśāstra. In Sanskrit, Dharma is used in the following meanings – law, truth, legal activity, virtue, religion, duty, and deity of law. The textual corpus of Dharmaśāstra is composed in poetic verses and are part of the Hindu Smṛti, constituting divergent commentaries and treatises on duties, responsibilities and ethics to oneself, to family and as a member of society. The texts include discussions of stages of life, social classes, and proper goals of life, personal virtues and duties such as non-violence against all living beings.

The Nirṇayasindhu is divided into three Pariccheda-s. The Prathamapariccheda deals with the basics of Kālamāna or Time Calculations ranging from Yuga-s; the Tithi-Vāra-Pakṣa-Māsa-Ayana-Samvatsara nirṇaya-s; the influence of Solar-Lunar-Planetary-Nakṣatra-s on Humanity and the Highlights of the Occasions that all Hindus tend to observe. Such opportunities include Social-Family-Individual Occurences. They are also outlets for recalling the Almighty by way of Stotra-Japa-Kīrtana-Vrata-Homa-Tīrthayātrā, various vrata-s and festivals to be performed during the year.

In the Prathamapariccheda of the Nirṇayasindhu is described the normal Tithi and such other nirṇaya-s, but specific details of māsa-Tithi nirṇaya-s were not described in detail. This is described in detail in the Dvitīyapariccheda, which delineates the Month-wise and other special aspects by way of Ground-Work references.

The Pūrvabhāga of the Tṛtīyapariccheda provides intricate details of dharmajñāna of human life right from the stage of Prathamarajasvalā, Garbhādhāna, Sīmantonnayana, Jātakarma, Nāmakaraṇa, Annaprāśana, Cūḍākarma, Vidyārambha, Upanayana, Brahmacārī dharma-s to Vivāha and Gṛhastadharma-s. The Uttarabhāga describes all types of Śrādhavidhi-s, Āśauca nirṇaya-s and Antyasamskāra-s, and also describes specific cases of Pitṛkṛtya-s, Darśādiśrāddha-s,Tarpana-s and Pitṛdānā-s.

msItem.author: Kamalākarabhaṭṭa
msItem.incipit: kāruṇyaikaniketanaṃ rāmaṃ sītālatāsuktam | viśvāmitrānvavāyavratatisamālambaśākhinam | lakṣmīsahāyaṃ kalpadrutalaṃ rañjitagokulam | barhāpīḍaṃ ghanaśyāmaṃ mahaḥ kiñcid upāsmahe | vedārthadharmarakṣāyai māyāmānuṣarūpiṇam | pitāmahaṃ hariṃ vande bhaṭṭanārāyaṇāhvayam | yatpādasaṃskṛtiḥ sarvamaṅgalapratibhūrmatā | tān bhaṭṭarāmakṛṣṇākhyān śrītātacaraṇānnumaḥ | sarvakalyāṇasaṃdohanidānaṃ yatpadadvayam | dyunadīsodarīm ambām umākhyāṃ naumi sādaram |
msItem.explicit: gotranāmādiniṣedhas tu śubhārthī prathamāntena vṛddhau saṃkalpam ācaret ity upakramya anasmadvṛddhaśabdānām ity ukteḥ saṃkalpaśrāddhaparaḥ | sapiṇḍake tu sarvaṃ bhavati iti prayogapārijātāt | gotranāmādibhir āmantrya pitṛbhyo py arghyaṃ pradāpayet iti chandogapariśiṣṭe tadvidhānāt | yat tu brāhme pitā pitāmahaś caiva tathaiva prapitāmahaḥ| trayo hy aśrumukhāhyete pitaraḥ parikīrtitāḥ| tebhyaḥ pūrvatarā ye ca prajāvantaḥ sukhaidhitā
msItem.finalRubric: iti śrīmīmāṃsakanārāyaṇabhaṭṭasūrisūnurāmakṛṣṇabhaṭṭātmajadivākarabhaṭṭānuja kamalākarabhaṭṭakṛte nirṇayasindhau prathamaḥ paricchedaḥ samāptaḥ |
